title: E field and isoline map - where does electron go

content.description: An electric field <math alttext="vector E" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mover accent="true"> <mi>E</mi> <mo>â†’</mo> </mover> </mstyle> </math> within a region of space is represented by the arrows shown in the figure. The dashed-line curves represent equipotential lines for three electric potentials, <math alttext="V sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="V sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="V sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>. An electron is released from rest at Point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> on the <math alttext="V sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> equipotential.
content.question: Which of the following correctly indicates the resulting motion of the electron and provides a valid justification?

choices.label: The electron will move toward the <math alttext="V sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> equipotential because electrons move toward stronger electric fields.

The electron will move toward the <math alttext="V sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> equipotential because electrons experience an electric force in the direction of the electric field.

The electron will move toward the <math alttext="V sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> equipotential because electrons move toward lower electric potentials.

The electron will move toward the <math alttext="V sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> equipotential because electrons always accelerate toward higher potential.

content.answer: The electron will move toward the <math alttext="V sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> equipotential because electrons always accelerate toward higher potential.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
